user.biography: We’re in business to save our home planet.

node.text: A live conversation with Patagonia fly fishing ambassador Riverhorse Nakadate and Save the Boundary Waters’ Samantha Chadwick. They discuss the making of “A Northern Light” and the threats currently facing the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness.

node.title: Patagonia Fly Fishing & Save the Boundary Waters Live Q&A

node.text: @outsidehilary can’t get @kellycordes to stand still for one phone call, but she does find out what his voting plan is. You’re 20% more likely to vote if you make a plan. We’re challenging the angling community to #MakeAPlanToVote and to #PassThePlan.

node.text:
Today, despite support from voters across the political spectrum, our public lands face unprecedented threats from extractive industries and the politicians in their pockets. Part love letter, part political exposé, Public Trust investigates how we arrived at this precarious moment through three heated conflicts—a national monument in the Utah desert, a mine in the Boundary Waters, and oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge—and makes a case for the continued protection of public lands.

@PulicTrustFilm produced by Jeremy Rubingh @jeremycoloradoboy and directed David Byars @byars_remorse

node.text:
The Elwha River is the site of a steelhead comeback. Prior to the removal of two dams that blocked the passage of anadromous fish, the summer run steelhead on the Elwha had essentially disappeared. But within just a few years of the dams coming down, previously landlocked fish were answering their genetic calling to the sea. In 2018, over 200 wild summer steelhead returned to the Elwha. Rising from the Ashes is a new story of resilience from Wild Steelheaders United (@wildsteelhead) and told beautifully by Shane Anderson (@northforkstudios).
#ItsAllHomeWater

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Patagonia Fly Fish in The Bahamas with @nick_onthefly, and @bonefishtarpontrust. May be an image of one or more people, ocean and text that says 'It's All Home Water Roots and recovery on Abaco am Islands.'.

node.text:
Hurricane Dorian brought devastating loss of life, a humanitarian crisis and startling environmental damage to the Bahamas. The 2019 storm battered a combined 69 square miles of mangrove forest on Abaco and Grand Bahama. These irreplaceable plants sequester carbon, filter pollutants, stabilize shorelines, protect against storm surges and provide wildlife habitat. Now, a coalition of bonefish guides, volunteers and scientists are leading the effort to restore this ecosystem.
Read the full story from @bonefishtarpontrust's Nick Roberts at the link in bio.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @nick_onthefly

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Patagonia Fly Fish on July 21, 2021 tagging @arianstevens, and @deschutesnative. May be an image of text that says 'MATT MENDES "I'm'a passionate person when it comes to these fish. want to take care of this for the Û future. It's tribal tradition. It's my family This is my story.'.

node.text:
“These are my home waters,” says Matt Mendes (@deschutesnative), a @nativefishsociety river steward, Deschutes River fly fishing guide and a guy who generally gets things done. “My granddad, Al Bagley, was the first Native American fly fishing guide in Oregon, so I don’t take it for granted. It’s a blessing—a privilege—for me to be out there.”
 
Though he puts in more than 200 river days per year, Matt works for wild fish, wild water and the people of the Warm Springs Indian Reservation for 365. From installing trash can stations at access points to leading river cleanups and marking spawning beds, he works tirelessly to mend, strengthen and enhance his environment. “I’m a passionate person when it comes to these fish. I want to take care of this fishery for the future. It’s tribal tradition. It’s my family. This is my story.”
 
His advice for activists: “The dams are the main culprit. But it’s also the foundational stuff—safe fish-handling practices; take care of riparian zones; be aware of spawning beds. Even taking care of those things could help wild steelhead numbers pop up.”

Each week we’ll be introducing a Wild Fish Activist. Know someone passionate about making a difference on their home water? Let us know in the comments—we’d love share their stoke with the community.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @arianstevens

node.text:
When Hurricane Dorian hit the Bahamas, bonefish guide Justin Sands was in the eye of the storm. “There were five different vehicles parked in my backyard, and I swam over the top of all of them and didn’t touch one of them,” said Sands. When it was over, 74 people had died, and the damage to the environment was startling. Dorian damaged or destroyed nearly 74 percent of Grand Bahama’s mangroves and 40 percent of Abaco’s mangroves—an essential component of a healthy flats habitat and a major factor in carbon sequestration. Now, a coalition of bonefish guides, volunteers and scientists are leading the effort to restore this habitat.
Read the full story from @bonefishtarpontrust's Nick Roberts at the link in bio.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @flatsbum73

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Patagonia Fly Fish on July 14, 2021 tagging @lesliehittmeier, and @emeraldlensmedia. May be an image of text that says 'EMERALD LAFORTUNE "We're all an example to somebody- that's a big par of activism Guiding, fishing and living in a small town is deeply grounded in my values-love and accountability.'.

node.text:
Wild Fish Activist: Emerald LaFortune (@emeraldlensmedia)
Fearless, dedicated, brave—an all-around badass. As part of a new group of women fly fishing guides on Idaho’s Middle Fork Salmon River, Emerald LaFortune has been an inspiration for, well, just about everyone. As a writer and relationship builder, Emerald’s passionate advocacy work and everyday courage have touched many communities. By standing alongside LGBTQ+ anglers and fighting to make sure there’s no place for homophobia in fly angling, Emerald has not only brought new energy to our sport, she’s worked to make it a more accepting place for all of us. Her work as a steward and protector of the Salmon River watershed looks forward to a day of healthy wild fish populations, including anadromous salmon and steelhead, and a free-flowing river. “I’ve always appreciated individuals who are authentic and clear because I learn a lot,” she says. “I may have a certain voice as a guide or a writer, but everyone has people they influence. We’re all an example to somebody—that’s a big part of activism. Guiding, fishing and living in a small town is deeply grounded in my values—love and accountability.”
 
“For me, wild fish activism is about humans working in collaboration with nature. That begins with respecting and honoring the approach of the Indigenous people who coexisted with these ecosystems for thousands of years.”

Each week we’ll be introducing a Wild Fish Activist. Know someone passionate about making a difference on their home water? Let us know in the comments—we’d love share their stoke with the community. 
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @lesliehittmeier

node.text:
Wild fish are only as healthy as the watersheds they inhabit.

Members of the Central Westcoast Forest Society position an alder tree into a restored side channel to create habitat for returning salmon in Clayoquot Sound, British Columbia.

Follow @patagonia_workwear for more stories about folks working to leave it better than they found it.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @jeremykoreski

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Patagonia Fly Fish in The Bahamas with @miahwatt, @nick_onthefly, @austin.trigg, @bahamasnationaltrust, @bonefishtarpontrust, @friendsoftheenvironment, and @flatsbum73. May be an image of text that says 'It's All Home Water Roots and recovery on Abaco and Grand Bahama Islands.'.

node.text:
The worst natural disaster in the Bahamas history, Hurricane Dorian left a staggering humanitarian crisis, claiming the lives of at least 74 people and displacing thousands. The storm also devastated the area’s mangrove forest—an essential component of a healthy flats habitat and a major factor in carbon sequestration. Now, a coalition of bonefish guides, volunteers and scientists are leading the effort to restore this habitat, breathe new life into this vital fishery and bolster coastal resilience.
Read the full story from @bonefishtarpontrust's Nick Roberts at the link in bio.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater

Photo: @miahwatt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Patagonia Fly Fish on July 02, 2021 tagging @keep.fish.wet, and @tenandtwoco. May be an image of text that says 'NO FISH DRY JULY'.

node.text:
This July, we encourage you to ask yourself “do I really need a photo of that fish?” With many places in North America enduring extreme drought and water temperatures much higher than normal, let's give the fish a break during one of the hottest months of the year by keeping them wet and releasing them quickly.

Head over to @keep.fish.wet to learn more and get entered into giveaways.  Stay tuned all month long to dig into the science on how water temp impacts our favorite ectotherms.
#KeepFishWet #WildFishActivism #itsallhomewater

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Patagonia Fly Fish in Argentina with @patagonia.arg, @patagoniachile, @greenpeacecl, @machadooutdoor, @robertogomezcoll, @puravidaecoaventura, @marianotorreok, @javiersi7, @linoadillon, @beaglesecretosdelmar, @sinazulnohayverde, @fernandogabrielencinas, @hermannfeldkamp, @kommerpabloenrique, @veleroksar, @juan.m.rivas, @shimawaia, @puebloyagan, @defendamos_chiloe, and @clubnauticoafasyn.

node.text:
Together, we saved the Beagle Channel!

Today, Tierra del Fuego in Argentina became the first place in the world to preemptively ban the salmon farming industry. After the threat of a Norwegian salmon farm emerged in 2018, communities in Chile and Argentina organized to stop it, culminating in a kayak paddle-out to protest. It all started with Artifishal and Estado Salmonero, films that expose the environmental, social and community disaster of salmon farming.

Tierra del Fuego Force—congratulations, Fuegians!

#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater #LeyDeSalmonicultura #NoALaSalmonicultura #TenemosLey

node.text:
A take-it-everywhere, fish-everything jacket that’s burly enough for an unexpected squall yet versatile enough for a choppy ride to the flats, the Ultralight Packable is a flat-out essential for roving fly anglers. Waterproof, breathable and quick-drying, the Ultralight doesn’t go light on fishy features, sporting a 3-layer H2No® Performance Standard shell, articulated arms, oversized fly-box pocket, tool dock, cinch cuffs, adjustable brimmed hood and corrosion-resistant zips. Even better, the innovative Ultralight packs into a tennis ball-sized stuff sack, so it’s always ready to hit the water.
#WildFishActivism #ItsAllHomeWater⁠
